Ron Jeffries wrote:

> On Thursday, November 6, 2003, at 2:31:21 PM, Dave Astels wrote:
> 
>  >> "Tests need to run against the background of a known set of objects.
>  >> This set of objects is called a test fixture.
> 
>  > Yes.  Ideally each INSTANCE of each SUBCLASS of the TestCase class
>  > embodies a single fixture.  The class describes that fixture.  By that
>  > I mean that all test methods in the class run in the context of that
>  > fixture in a maximally cohesive way (i.e. it is not the case that some
>  > tests uses part of the fixture and other tests use some other part of
>  > the fixture).
> 
> Dave, as I read the JUnit text it is saying that the classes under test are
> the fixture, not that the TestCase subclass is the fixture. You seem to be
> saying that the TestCase subclass is the fixture.

Pardon me, Ron. If every instance of a class is the same, then there is 
not much point in distinguishing between object and class, except if 
you're talking to a compiler. As you doubtless know, one commonly says 
that a collection has a property if all its elements have that property. 
It's just a kind of verbal shorthand.

Thus, the TestCase subclass is, in effect, the fixture: all 
freshly-initialized instances of that class (as in, after invoking 
setUp) represent the same fixture state.

Does that statement compile? No. But then we're not compilers. :)
